Do you have a personal essay to share with the world? Please email it to jack.crone@mailonline.co.uk or mail it to: Letters, The Guardian, 60 Old Brompton Road, London, SW7 4LD .

title: ‘You just have to laugh’: five teachers on dealing with ‘six-seven’ in the classroom
summary: School pupils have been shouting out the words 'six-seven' in lessons . The latest meme-based craze has swept through classrooms across the UK . While some teachers have stoically ignored the trend, others have embraced it . Here, five teachers explain how they're coping with the latest internet craze . 'If you give oxygen to it, then it becomes an inferno', says James, a secondary school teacher, north London . ‘They want to feel a part of a group. Whatever the latest craze is, they want to feel part of it. It’s what kids do', says Connor, a history teacher, London comprehensive . ’Skibidi toilet' was a popular meme back when I was at my training school, but it didn’t really exist as much in the classroom. Unlike “six-seven”, “skibidi toilet” was never written on the board in class, so students were less able to pick up on it. Then they’ll be on to the next thing .

title: There must be an Engels (playing with my chart)
summary: The research on which you report reads like a deliberate attempt to diminish the nature and extent of class differences . In Moss Side and Hulme in the 1970s and 80s there were some professional people living there whom I knew, but the overwhelming majority of inhabitants were working class . To suggest class was not that important is surely to throw the baby out with the bathwater . Emily Chung has used modern historical research methods to suggest that Friedrich Engels’ 1844 study of the Manchester working class was as much polemic as social investigation . The same might be said of Henry Mayhew’s journalistic investigations of the London working class from 1849 .

title: Oxford Union condemns president-elect’s reported comments on Charlie Kirk shooting
summary: Charlie Kirk, 31, was killed at a Utah Valley University show on Wednesday . George Abaraonye became president-elect of the debating society in June . He reportedly posted comments in a WhatsApp group after Kirk's death . One message said: 'Charlie Kirk got shot, let's fucking go', according to reports . Abaraonye said he had 'reacted impulsively' to the news of Kirk's shooting . In response, the Oxford Union condemned the student's comments . It said it 'firmly opposes all forms of political violence and strongly stands by our commitment to free speech and considerate debate' Donald Trump paid tribute to Kirk as a 'martyr for truth and freedom'

title: Former West Coast player Mitch Brown becomes first AFL player to come out as bisexual
summary: Mitch Brown has become the first male AFL player, past or present, to come out as gay or bisexual . The 36-year-old played 94 matches for West Coast in a career that ended in 2016 . He identifies as a bisexual man and is in a long-term relationship with a woman . Brown said it would have been difficult had he spoken publicly during his playing career . But he was motivated to help change the culture within the sport . 'Empathy is powerful,' he said. 'What matters to me most is a sense of change' The news was widely welcomed on social media . In addition to messages from fans and supporters, the AFL Players' Association described the post as 'powerful' and the GWS Giants' account responded with a heart emoji .

title: The NHL preached inclusion. So why has it got into bed with Donald Trump?
summary: NHL commissioner Gary Bettman was named to Donald Trump's sports council last week . The council will play an important role in restoring tradition to college athletics, including keeping men out of women's sports . This is not the first time Bettman has given mixed messages around social issues . In 2023, the NHL tried to host a career fair aimed at recruiting a more diverse workforce . That event caught the attention of the governor’s office, which accused the NHL of discrimination – against white people . Bettman called the furor around Pride-themed jerseys a distraction from the intended message . Harrison Browne, the first transgender player in professional hockey, called the move 'deeply disturbing and a huge step backwards in making hockey a more inclusive sport'

title: Inclusive Brighton is perfect venue for World Cup’s sell-out party weekend
summary: England play Australia on Saturday, New Zealand play Ireland on Sunday . Last time the Rugby World Cup went to Brighton they made a movie about how it all worked out . This time, the movie has come before the match . World Rugby is releasing a short film called Where We Belong, directed by the duo Pip + Lib, emphasising rugby’s inclusivity . The executive team is all-female . So are the artists who created the opening TV credits, the DJs, and the groundstaff at the final . It’s the nature of a rugby team that it ought to be one place where anyone who wants to play can belong . There was a good handful of very shy girls who didn’t even really want to look at you, like young, awkward teenagers . But then they’re on the pitch and they were just like a completely different person . When they are working in football, the girls all want to show off how many keepy-uppies they can do .

title: UFC landed a $7.7bn deal with Paramount. But is Dana White’s Trump bond a liability?
summary: Dana White has long sought to expand the sport’s appeal to as many demographics as possible . In the past few years, he has bet big on a tight affiliation with Donald Trump . White has campaigned for Trump, welcomed him to several UFC events and hasn’t immediately smacked down the notion of holding a UFC card at the White House . While Maga champions an “America First” ideology, the UFC is a paragon of globalism . There’s a case to be made that if the Kamala Harris campaign had managed to get her on Rogan’s podcast last fall, we would have a different president today . The UFC’s primary demographic of young adult men proved to be a decisive force for Trump’s return to the presidency . This group overlaps significantly with the audience for UFC commentator Joe Rogan’s popular podcast, and Rogan – who felt ostracized by the left after touting scientifically unsound Covid treatments – endorsed Trump last year .

title: Freedom and joy: Rugby World Cup’s quirky quality sets it apart from the pack
summary: The current Women's Rugby World Cup is one of largely lopsided scorelines . Only five of the 28 fixtures have been decided by fewer than 14 points . But there remains a profound and unanimous pleasure to be had across the entire affair . Even as it has taken its slickly commercialised place in a crammed calendar of global sporting events, this Rugby World Cup still seems fuelled by a radiant and irrepressible delight . The core of rugby union’s appeal is its eclecticism and the personalities that beam from the women’s game are one-of-a-kind . More than a year ago, industry insiders involved in women’s sport were predicting the captivating success of this World Cup . They arrived on the back of a Lionesses campaign and in the wake of Ilona Maher’s single-handed social media takeover of rugby union . Other sports – and more pertinently their investors – will be analysing this fan engagement and wondering how to replicate it .

title: The USTA’s censorship of Trump dissent at the US Open is cowardly, hypocritical and un-American
summary: The United States Tennis Association has asked broadcasters not to show dissent against Donald Trump during Sunday's US Open men's final . In making that pre-emptive concession, the USTA has committed an unforced error that can't be undone . For the USTA to draw the line at showing boos for a sitting president is not 'policy consistency' but capitulation . It shows how much Trump's first term - and his bullying of cultural institutions - still shapes behavior . The Open is supposed to be New York's tournament, brash and multicultural, where the crowd is as much a presence as the players on the court . By sanitizing its reaction, the USTA isn't just shielding Trump. It is stripping the event of its unique character, authenticity and integrity . This year's theme, '75 years of breaking barriers' honors Althea Gibson, who in 1950 became the first Black player to compete at the tournament's predecessor, the US nationals .

title: I played in the NFL. Outrage over male cheerleaders is really about attempts to control masculinity
summary: Earlier this month, the Minnesota Vikings unveiled their newly minted 35-member cheerleading squad . It wasn’t just the choreography that caught attention, but the fact that two male performers, Blaize Shiek and Louie Conn, were part of the group . Almost immediately, reactions erupted online, from heartfelt support to calls for a boycott, and even a homophobic slur wielded by a former NFL player . Amid the storm, the Vikings stood firm . What this backlash really reveals is not fear of change, but fear of visibility . The outrage over male cheerleaders isn’t about sports. It’s about control: over masculinity, over image, and over who gets to be seen and celebrated in public spaces . When you peel back the helmets and hits, you’ll see what’s always been there: joy, vulnerability, brotherhood, and the undeniable truth that masculinity isn’t fixed .

title: ‘My time in the sun’: Rory McIlroy on Ryder Cup hopes and Masters glory
summary: Rory McIlroy returns to the Ryder Cup arena as the sixth man in history to complete a career grand slam . The Northern Irishman was at the centre of drama involving US fans and Patrick Reed in 2016 at Hazeltine . McIlroy could have faced Patrick Cantlay, for whom LaCava caddies, in match three on that Ryder Cup Sunday. The venue for this interview serves as an endearing reminder of McIlroy’s march into the pantheon of greats . Rory McIlroy: I think the only way he gets attention is by mentioning other people. To get attention he will mention me or Scottie [Scheffler] or others. I just think when you go into that environment and you are there for five or six days and the crowd are on you for eight hours, so many days in a row, it is inevitable it will get to someone or get to us as a group at some point. We are just going to have to do a really good job of managing that, having each other’s backs and protecting each other.

title: Trump’s strongman image got boos at the US Open, and perhaps that was the point
summary: Trump's presence at the US Open men's final was intended as a distraction . Not a distraction for him; lord knows, he couldn't care less about the actual match . If Trump was motivated by a patriotic love for tennis, he would have rocked up a day earlier for the women's final . But for Trump the prospect of cheering on Jersey girl Amanda Anisimova and her epic comeback story clearly wasn't juicy enough . After the golden escalator ride to kick off his 2015 presidential campaign and the fiery announcement speech hitting out at immigrants and foreigners, he effectively became spectator non-grata in Flushing . The New York crowd – the heart of the Open – never cottoned to his faux-gold flash and didn't hesitate to jeer his big screen pop-ups even then . It broke from the markedly lower profiles of past presidents and was over-the-top, even for a sport that regularly hosts royal families .

title: NFL 2025 season predictions: will it be Mahomes, Jackson or Allen in the Super Bowl?
summary: This will be the year of ... The Micah Parsons revenge tour . Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones’s idiotic decision to trade Parsons to Green Bay is set to be franchise-altering for both teams . The most underrated team this year is ... Last season ended with a playoff win, but it still felt underwhelming thanks to an offensive line that hung Stroud out to dry . Chicago Bears may not win a ton of games in the loaded NFC North, but Ben Johnson will make the most of Caleb Williams in the QB’s second season . Denver Broncos could reform the Monsters of the Midway. Not a playoff team in 2025, but an opponent nobody will want to face . Los Angeles Rams would walk into the postseason if everything goes their way. Matthew Stafford dealing with a herniated disc feels like a case of when, not if, he is replaced by Jimmy Garoppolo . Minnesota Vikings managed a 14-3 regular-season record in the brutal NFC North last year, but they did on the back of Sam Darnold’s unpredictably great season .

title: The biggest takeaway from Izak Rankine’s case is to remember why these rules exist at all
summary: The response to Izak Rankine’s homophobic slur was the sheer stupidity of it . Perhaps more than any other section of society, footballers are educated, counselled and warned . The laws of the game, particularly around ruck contests and holding the ball, are increasingly incomprehensible . What’s more contested is landing on an appropriate penalty . For this player, for this club, and at this stage of a long, grinding and finally fruitful rebuild, four weeks may as well be four years . Part of the problem here is that the AFL has forfeited much of the moral high ground . Eddie McGuire is beholden to almost no-one in football . Hopefully it's a chance to reflect on the reason the rule was there in the first place .

title: NFL preseason storylines: Cowboys chaos, the Browns‘ QB circus and Aaron Rodgers’ last dance
summary: Micah Parsons has requested a trade from the Dallas Cowboys . Cowboys owner Jerry Jones has allowed talks with Parsons to drag on . Jones has spent the offseason taking odd shots at his best player . The Vikings have a championship-caliber roster . They are loaded on both sides of the line of scrimmage . If JJ McCarthy slots into the Vikings’ offense is perhaps the most important variable in the championship race . Minnesota could have run it back with Darnold after a 14-win season, giving them a buffer to the McCarthy era. They bet on their infrastructure, allowing Darnold to walk and clearing the path for McCarthy. If McCarthy can be a solid starter in his debut season, the Vikings will have legitimate title aspirations. The Browns’ quarterback circus circus carried the Vikings through tough stretches last season. This year, their unit is deeper and more explosive, with veterans Jonathan Allen and Javon Hargrave offering extra punch up front . Click here for more NFL news .

title: $54m to walk: getting fired as a college football coach is a booming industry
summary: LSU relieved Kelly of his coaching duties after his Tigers suffered a resounding home loss to Texas A&M that dropped them out of the AP’s ranking of college football’s top 25 teams . While the terms of Kelly’s departure have yet to be resolved, his contract puts the school on the hook for 90% of his deal balance if he’s fired for cause – a final tab that comes to around $54m . The college football season is barely past the midpoint, and already 10 coaches have been fired with schools owing $169m in buyouts, including six in the elite Power 4 conferences . But ultimately it’s Kelly who makes the more convenient among media and fans for a college coaching buyout craze run amok . Even though the money used to pay these buyouts mostly comes out of TV deals and sponsorships that athletic departments rake in, it’s not hard to imagine the scholarships that could be awarded or the women’s and Olympic sports programs that could be reinstated with all that cash .

title: Lando Norris hits the front in title race with emphatic F1 Mexico City GP win
summary: Norris now leads Piastri by one point with Verstappen in third, 36 behind . The two McLaren teammates lead the charge then but the defending champion is still very much in the game . Norris, dominant and unchallenged from the moment he held the lead through turn one, this was a huge result - the first time he has held the lead of the championship since before the Saudi Arabian GP in April . He held his lead in a breathtaking run on the drag to turn one as the leaders went three abreast . Piastri had a shocking start, dropping amid the jostling down the straight from seventh to 10th. He had to fight back across the remaining 70 laps and did well to make it to fifth, including a decisive move on George Russell on lap 61 .

title: Lando Norris claims F1 Mexico City GP pole as teammate Oscar Piastri falters
summary: Norris delivered perhaps his best lap of the season in qualifying . He beat the Ferraris of Charles Leclerc and Lewis Hamilton into second and third . His fellow title protagonists Max Verstappen and Oscar Piastri, Norris’s McLaren teammate, could manage only fifth and eighth fastest respectively . The pole was a real statement of intent from Norris and McLaren . If he wins and Piastri finishes below fourth, the British driver will hold the lead of the championship for the first time since the fifth round of the season . CLICK HERE for all the latest Formula One news . WATCH: Lando Norris takes pole in Mexico City Grand Prix . Lewis Hamilton: I'm honoured to be up here with Charles and Lando, these guys have been so quick all year .

title: The Shane Warne effect: why some cricketers are loved by fans of their fiercest rivals
summary: Shane Warne terrorised English cricket for 15 years . Few visiting players have been booed so loudly or applauded so enthusiastically . Kohli redefined expectations and symbolised the self-assured, unapologetic India of the 21st century . AB de Villiers never played for India, but you wouldn’t know it . Despite cricket’s devotion to an idealised code of conduct its rivalries seem to be built from harder, more ancient stones . The longer you let the narrative settle, the harder it is to hold on to hate for some players who, whether we like it or not, have earned our respect. In the end, all the noise settles into admiration for their skill and their spirit, for the breathe to play this strange, beautiful game in a way no one else quite can.

title: ‘My Netflix show would be White Collar to World Champion’: Fabio Wardley on his boxing journey
summary: Fabio Wardley takes on Joseph Parker at the O2 in London on Saturday . It is nine years since Parker beat Andy Ruiz Jr to win the WBO world heavyweight title . Wardley was commuting from Ipswich to London where he worked for a recruitment agency . His task then, apart from the occasional scrap on the whitecollar circuit, was to find jobs for health and social workers . Years later, he risks his health every time he climbs into the ring . The canvas resembled a Jackson Pollock painting, with most of the blood shed by Wardley, and both fighters went to dark places during a battle that ended in a draw .  Wardley was initially a footballer, who played for the academy at his cherished Ipswich Town, and he only discovered boxing years after he met Robert Hodgins . On Saturday he returns to the same venue where he lost something of his soul. “The O2 Arena will always have a piece of my soul. I left a little bit of me in that ring, against Parker,” he says .

title: NFL bets big on Saudi Arabia with Tom Brady-led flag football showcase
summary: The Fanatics Flag Football Classic, headlined by seven-time Super Bowl champion Tom Brady, will take place on 21 March 2026, at Kingdom Arena in Riyadh . The showcase event is expected to serve as a major lead-in to flag football’s debut at the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles . It will feature three teams of eight players facing off in a round-robin tournament, with the top two advancing to a championship game . For the league, the event could mark the start of a new chapter – one where flag football becomes a global phenomenon . But for critics, it’s part of a much bigger debate about what role Saudi Arabia – and its billions – should play in the world of sports . Its push has included the launch of LIV Golf in 2022, lucrative deals to attract some of the world’s top soccer players .

title: Hull KR secure treble with dominant display against Wigan in Super League Grand Final
summary: Hull KR defeated Wigan Warriors 30-6 in the Super League Grand Final . Joe Burgess scored a late try to seal the Robins' first league title since 1985 . Willie Peters' side were bottom of the Super League as recently as 2020 . They are only the fifth club to win the Grand Final, with Leeds the last team to win it for the first time in 2004 . Wigan's Brad O'Neill was sent to the sin-bin after a dangerous tackle on Tyrone May. Within two minutes, Hull KR went ahead as the outstanding Mikey Lewis cut through to score between the posts . With O'Neill still off the field the Robins went further in front as a fine passage of play led to the former Wigan winger Burgess touching down . A penalty from Adam Keighran on the stroke of half-time got Wigan on the board and when Harry Smith scored shortly after the restart, a comeback appeared to be on the cards .

title: I was born into the Broncos’ last dynasty but this Sunday could be the sweetest victory of all
summary: Allan Langer was the pint-sized prince of Queensland. His height and cheeky grin belied a will to win more like a Roman gladiator . For diehard fans like Dad, the Broncos were Queensland’s team . The Broncos – and their million-plus fans – were unfamiliar with the grief of grand final defeat . Post-Bennett, the Broncos had become the very thing they were created to overthrow . Cameron Smith, Billy Slater and Cooper Cronk found glory at the Melbourne Storm under Craig Bellamy .  Johnathan Thurston – deemed too small by Broncos scouts – became a future immortal at the North Queensland Cowboys . In 2024, an injury-plagued Broncos finished 12th. So, they hired a ticket inspector: Michael “Madge” Maguire . Some Broncos old boys were dirty about sacking a favourite son for a southerner. They browbeat the board into making Kevin Walters the new coach . Reece Walsh, Ezra Mam and Kotoni Staggs evoked those bygone Broncos greats. The Panthers won their third straight premiership .

title: Sonay Kartal pulls off biggest win of career to stun world No 5 Mirra Andreeva
summary: Sonay Kartal beat world No 5 Mirra Andreeva 7-5, 2-6, 7-5 . The victory in Beijing marks Kartal’s first defeat of a top 10 opponent . Jannik Sinner continued to piece together one of the greatest seasons of his career as he clinched his 21st career title at the China Open . Sinner’s victory marks his third title of 2025 and he has reached the final in seven of eight tournaments, including all four slams . Gal Monfils has announced that he will retire after the 2026 season . Carlos Alcaraz withdrew shortly after his win in Tokyo in order to manage an ankle injury . There is no rest for most of the best players in a gruelling season. The ATP Tour moves on to the Shanghai Masters, the penultimate ATP Masters 1000 event .

title: The Chiefs have committed the greatest crime in sports: making Patrick Mahomes dull
summary: There is a different tenor about the Chiefs these days . At the peak of their championship run, the Chiefs didn’t just beat opponents, they demoralized them . Now, anything outside freelancing looks like hard work . The bombs away style of early a year has made way for a more plodding approach . Their aging tight end is effectively overexposed and hope is out of the question . Despite winning 15 to 11 one-leg-a-season, the Chiefs’ offense was more than 11 full-field style plays . Last year, Travis Kelce took the left tackle spot was a chore . This year, rookie Xavier Worthy took the left spot and has been uninspired . There is a lack of rhythm and synchronicity on the offensive side of the ball . They’re not the Super Bowl champs they were three years ago, but they are not the irrepressible force they were . If they lose Sunday, they'll sink to 1-3, falling further behind the Chargers in AFC West .

title: Terence Crawford stuns Canelo Álvarez to become undisputed super middleweight champion
summary: Terence Crawford defeats Canelo lvarez to become undisputed super-middleweight champion of the world . Crawford moves up two weight classes to hand the Mexican superstar only the third defeat of his career . The judges scored it 116-112, 115-113 and 115-113, all for Crawford, who improves to 42-0 with 31 knockouts . Already the first man of the four-belt era to unify titles in two weight classes, the Nebraskan now adds a fifth . It elevates him from generational talent into the all-time realm of lionhearted weight-jumpers like Harry Greb, Henry Armstrong, Roberto Durn and Manny Pacquiao . Allegiant Stadium, the $2bn home of the NFL’s Raiders, had never hosted a fight prior to Saturday night. The crowd more than doubled the previous Las Vegas record of 29,214 set in 1982, when Larry Holmes battered Gerry Cooney to defend the heavyweight title .

title: NFL panic meter: Is Russell Wilson cooked? Is the Chiefs’ golden age over?
summary: Russell Wilson looked like the same player he was in Pittsburgh . Daniel Jones is now with the Colts, and carved up the Dolphins’ defense . Mike McDaniel's shtick is already wearing thin with the ‘Phins fanbase . Buffalo lacked the bodies to match up with Baltimore’s heavier personnel . The Bills play more dime defence (six defensive backs) than any team in the league, but have one of the weakest safety groups . Janson Dart flashed enough in preseason to earn the starting gig . There are plenty of other threats in the postseason, and early evidence suggests the Chiefs may not be the team to beat . title: Alcaraz too strong as he beats Djokovic in straight sets to reach US Open final
summary: Carlos Alcaraz beat Novak Djokovic 6-4, 7-6 (4), 6-2 in US Open semi-final . Alcaraz will play Jannik Sinner or Félix Auger-Aliassime in the final . The 22-year-old is the third youngest man in the open era to reach seven grand slam finals, behind only Bjrn Borg and Rafael Nadal . Djokovic had not competed since Wimbledon before this tournament . Just reaching a fourth grand slam semi-final in 2025 was an immense achievement for the 38-year-old Serb . Click here for more from the US Open . READ: Alcaraz and Djokovic go head-to-head in epic battle of tennis greats . CLICK HERE for all the latest from Flushing Meadows .

title: Halal tech: how Muslim-friendly websites and apps blossomed in 2024
summary: LaunchGood has become a household name and has enabled its largely Muslim user base to raise nearly $700m . Launched by Amany Killawi and Chris Blauvelt and Omar Hamid, it has become the primary gateway for many during Ramadan .  Killawi has stepped away from her day-to-day responsibilities as chief operating officer of LaunchGood to start a sister company, a payments processor called PayGood in 2024 . Aim is to provide for Muslim businesses and charities what LaunchGood’s team had to hack together for themselves: a reliable payment system that doesn’t discriminate . Recent study found Muslims were more likely than other faith groups to have their accounts at banks and other US financial institutions closed, investigated or otherwise challenged . PayPal stopped providing services to Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza in 2021 . Muslim and pro-Palestinian founders have begun to question the leadership at Stripe . PayGood, which is still in beta, has begun to emerge as an alternative to major payments processors such as Stripe and PayPal .

title: As big tech grows more involved in Gaza, Muslim workers are wrestling with a spiritual crisis
summary: There’s been protests within American tech companies against their contracts with Israel and its military since the start of the war in Gaza . Some staff have resigned and some have been fired for their activism . But as the war endures and Palestinians in Gaza are being starved, forcibly displaced and killed, and the contracts have survived, there’s a growing group of Muslim staffers who are unsure whether they can religiously justify working at companies that they view as effectively defense contractors . One Google worker said they decided it no longer feels halal to remain at the company because the role was a blessing from God . Others worried that leaving the company would do more harm than good . Nearly all said that the public protest of Aboussad, and her co-demonstrator Vaniya Agrawal, has pressed the question . The reasons vary: some feel they can do more to agitate against these contracts from inside the company, others worry about being able to provide for their families and some worry about trying to find another tech job in a tough market.

title: Meta AI adviser spreads disinformation about shootings, vaccines and trans people
summary: Robby Starbuck, 36, of Nashville, was appointed in August as an adviser by Meta – owner of Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and other tech platforms . Since his appointment, Starbuck has baselessly claimed that individual shooters in the US were motivated by leftist ideology . He has also described faith-based protest groups as communists, and without evidence tied Democratic lawmakers to murders . Starbuck’s online posts have not changed in tenor since his appointment was brought into the Meta fold . His Trump administration connections raise broader questions about the extent to which corporate America has capitulated to the Maga movement . The Guardian repeatedly contacted Meta for comment on Starbuck’s role, and his rhetoric online, but received no response . In part, he responded: “It seems your piece is an attempted hit job meant to punish Meta for working with me on AI fairness. Nothing I’ve said has been on behalf of Meta – they work with people from every political background”.

title: ‘One day I overheard my boss saying: just put it in ChatGPT’: the workers who lost their jobs to AI
summary: Radio Krakw launched programmes hosted by three AI characters . Each had AI-generated photographs, a biography and a specific personality . One of the first shows was an interview with Polish poet Wisawa Szymborska . Szyborska is a symbol of Polish intellectual culture, so it caused outrage . Tens of thousands of people signed a petition to get the AI shows taken off air . Hundreds of young people didn’t want to listen to an AI show . The station has since scrapped the avatars, largely because of the success of our campaign . It’s now student-run. The station claim this is about offering mentorship, but it’s also a cheaper alternative to hiring qualified journalists .  Lina Meilina, 30, illustrator, Bandung, Indonesia, has been drawing and painting since she was a kid . Most of my income comes from commissions: I draw bespoke characters for clients, and also create my own .

title: UK TikTokers say goodbye to US followers as ban looms: ‘It’s a really beautiful community’
summary: TikTok is a video-sharing app with 170 million American users . Creators and business owners have told the Guardian they will lose out . A US-sized hole will appear in the global userbase . TikTok has become a key gateway to Americans for the UK’s online video creators . Several UK-based creators and one entrepreneur who all say they will be affected by a ban . Jay Beech, 30, says there is a strong relationship between creators and users on both sides of the Atlantic . Em Wallbank, 25, says her comedy skits have been a hit across the Atlantic partly due to her accent . Sarah Yuma, 30, says a US TikTok audience has been crucial to the growth of her business . Fats Timbo, 28, is a comedian and disability activist who posts content to her 3 million followers on TikTok . She says the platform’s US reach – approximately a quarter of her following – has been vital for her work .

title: How the far right is weaponising AI-generated content in Europe
summary: This year’s European parliamentary elections were the launchpad for a rollout of AI-generated campaigning by the European far right . The use of the same models and themes and the same approach to presenting and packaging the images has given rise to a common aesthetic across borders . In Germany, the issue reached the independent oversight board of Mark Zuckerberg’s Meta when the body opened an investigation into anti-immigration content on Facebook . It is part of a wave of AI-made rightwing content on social media networks . Posts elsewhere from Europe’s political extremes range from the Italian far right’s deployment of “photo-realistic” images of women and children eating insects to bolster a conspiracy theory about the intentions of “a global elite”, to Irish far-right images of a police officer stamping on Ireland’s flag and Islamophobic memes in the immediate aftermath of the Southport knife murders in the UK . One image depicted bearded men in traditional Islamic dress outside parliament, with one waving a knife, behind a crying child in a union jack T-shirt.

title: Meta scrapped factcheckers ‘because systems were too complex’
summary: Helle Thorning-Schmidt, co-chair of Meta's oversight board, said the company's systems had become 'too complex' Mark Zuckerberg announced Meta would move away from using third-party checkers to flag misleading content in favour of user-based notes . The decision by Meta, which also owns Instagram, WhatsApp and Threads, has been widely criticised by online safety campaigners and commentators . Linda Yaccarino, the head of X, welcomed Meta’s decision, saying 'welcome to the party' during an appearance at the CES technology show in Las Vegas . She said X's community notes were 'good for the world' and the system was 'the most effective, fastest factchecking, without bias' Zuckerberg called Meta's current moderation system 'too politically biased' but said changes would mean 'we're going to catch less bad stuff'

title: Users of ‘throuples’ dating app Feeld may have had intimate photos accessed
summary: Users of Feeld, a dating app aimed at alternative relationships, could have had sensitive data accessed or even edited . British cybersecurity company claims to have uncovered serious failings in Feeld’s systems earlier this year . Feeld said it had dealt with the concerns “as a matter of urgency”, resolved them within two months and that it had not seen any evidence that user data had been breached . Fortbridge researchers found that it was possible to read other people’s messages exchanged in chats and even see attachments . Messages could be edited and deleted, the researchers found, and chats deleted by the users could be recovered . Time-limited photos and videos, commonly used to share explicit images that self-delete after one viewing, could be retrieved and seen indefinitely, by accessing a link available to the sender .

title: Racism, misogyny, lies: how did X become so full of hatred? And is it ethical to keep using it?
summary: I considered leaving Twitter as soon as Elon Musk acquired it in 2022, just not wanting to be part of a community that could be bought . I joined the rival platform Mastodon, but fast realised that I would never get 70,000 followers on there like I had on Twitter . There’s something eerie and a bit depressing about a social media feed that doesn’t refresh often enough, like walking into a shopping mall where half the shops have closed down and the rest are all selling the same thing . X began sharing ad revenues with its ‘premium’ users, and I joined Threads . All I ever see on it is strangers confessing to boring misdemeanours . People get paid, indirectly through advertising, for engagement . Is X sharing it 50/50? Or 10/90? Are they actually paying you to generate hatred? Is X any worse than Facebook, or TikTok, or (for God’s sake!) YouTube?

title: Musk’s giant Tesla factory casts shadow on lives in a quiet corner of Germany
summary: Residents of Grnheide, Germany are concerned about the impact of Tesla's factory . Founder Elon Musk has backed far-right parties and appeared to make Nazi salute . As sales have declined, shifts at the factory have been reduced from three to two a day . The shock caused by the incident was palpable on the factory floor, workers said . Locals are also worried about the potential impact of the plant on the region's pine forests and groundwater . Residents joke among themselves about what might take the place of the factory, should Tesla fail . They also worry about the impact on their rural community, which is characterised by its woodlands, lakes and rivers . In the meantime unsold Teslas have been moved on transporters en masse to a former East German airport 60km (37 miles) away, where, hidden behind trees and parked alongside solar panels, they bake in the sun . On Kununu, a job portal where employees can anonymously vent their feelings about their workplace, one Tesla worker has written: 'The brand once stood for cosmopolitanism, progress, and tolerance, but now it stands for the exact opposite'

title: Fear, hope and loathing in Elon Musk’s new city: ‘It’s the wild, wild west and the future’
summary: Starbase is a rocket-manufacturing facility and launch arena in Texas . It is also the site of the multibillionaire’s latest venture to acquire more political power . The 280 eligible voters will approve the incorporation of a new, 4 sq km municipality . There remain many questions about why the company, which did not respond to any of my written questions and interview requests, would move for such recognition . While downtown Starbase may be a little averse to visitors, it’s a different story outside . Musk founded the facility in late 2014, and its rapid expansion in recent years has drawn a small platoon of Mars obsessives to the area . Many are livestreamers and photographers who document the minutiae of Starbase’s activities in extraordinary detail . As the US lurches further into what many describe as an era of norm-shattering digital dystopia under the second presidency of Donald Trump, the goings-on here, in this remote enclave by the US-Mexico border, already bring a sense of grisly prescience .

title: Fears for UK boomer radicalisation on Facebook after Meta drops factcheckers
summary: Mark Zuckerberg announced Meta would replace factcheckers with a crowdsourced system and recommend more political content . Experts fear the decision will exacerbate so-called boomer radicalisation in the UK . Anti-extremism campaign group Hope not Hate said it feared Zuckerberg’s announcement was a prelude to far-right figures and groups being allowed back on to Facebook . An Ofcom report last year found that overall, social media users were most likely to describe Facebook as their main social media site (48%), but added that older adults were less likely to recognise a fake social media profile . Dr Natalie-Anne Hall, a lecturer at Cardiff University, said Facebook was a key site for algorithmically driven encounters with harmful ideas within people’s everyday practices of social media use .

title: TikTok’s algorithm is highly sensitive – and could send you down a hate-filled rabbit hole before you know it
summary: Last week we reported how Facebook and Instagram’s algorithms are luring young men into the Manosphere . This week, we explore what happens when TikTok’s algorithm is unleashed on a blank account in the absence of any interactions such as liking or commenting . In April, Guardian Australia set up a new TikTok account on a completely blank smartphone linked to a new, unused email address . Initially it was difficult to identify a clear theme to the video being served through the app . Then the Wakeley church stabbing attack happened on 15 April . For the first two days of the experiment, TikTok served up generic content about Melbourne, where the phone was located, along with videos about iPhone hacks . On day three, Tik Tok news content began appearing, coinciding with the stabbing attack on bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel at the Assyrian Christ the Good Shepherd church in the Sydney suburb of Wakeley . It wasn’t the video of the stabbing itself, but rather videos of Emmanuel’s evocative and conservative Christian sermons .

title: Tech chiefs tell Trump to call off troops – will Firefox go ‘full AI’?
summary: Multiple major players in artificial intelligence are focusing their efforts on new browsers with deep AI integrations . The head of Firefox talks about whether users maintain any expectation of privacy in this new era of personalized, agentic browsing . Donald Trump said he would not deploy the US national guard to San Francisco after proclaiming he would for weeks . Tech billionaires are getting what they paid for when donating to Trump, a direct line and an exemption for their home turf from his capricious use of force. The presence of tech billionaire donors, going by Trump’s Truth Social Post, is an image that emerges is a billionaire who wants to have his cake (be close to Trump) and eat it too. The Illinois governor, JB Pritzker, who has protested against the deployment of the national guard to Chicago for weeks, is also an avowed Democrat and no friend of Trump. One can surmise why his phone calls to the White House didn’t have the same result as Nvidia’s Jensen Huang’s did.

title: Dan and Phil’s relationship revelation is a reminder of how toxic fandoms can be
summary: Longtime British YouTubers Dan Howell and Phil Lester have been in a secret romantic relationship for 16 years . In a new video, the pair share the emotional damage that toxic fandoms can wreak on their subjects . The term 'stan' originates from Eminem's titular 2000 song about a fan so disturbed by his obsession with an artist that he ends up committing a murder suicide . Just in August, Amazon shared a PSA fans of its hit show The Summer I Turned Pretty, instructing them that there was a ‘zero tolerance policy for bullying and hate speech’ In late 2019, K-pop idol Goo Hara took her own life after being subject to severe online harassment . Last year pop star Shawn Mendes spoke publicly against the widespread rumours about his sexuality from so-called fans .

title: ‘Cancel Netflix’: Elon Musk leads rightwing backlash over trans character in kids’ show
summary: Musk has repeatedly encouraged his 227 million followers on X to cancel their Netflix subscriptions . In the past three days alone, he has posted or reposted calls to cancel Netflix for its content at least 26 times . He has called out pro-trans themes in shows such as The Baby-Sitters Club and Cocomelon . Musk is the father of a trans daughter, Vivian Wilson, who has publicly criticized her father's anti-trans vendetta . This is not the first time Netflix has come under fire from the right; in 2020, outrage over its film Cuties, which depicted underage actors performing sexualized dance routines, led to a spike in US customer cancellations, though it receded within days. Netflix has not publicly responded to Musk’s taunts .

title: YouTube agrees to pay Trump $24.5m to settle lawsuit over account suspension
summary: The case against YouTube had been closed in 2023, but Trump’s lawyers filed to reopen the case after he won the presidency . YouTube first suspended Trump’s channel for seven days on 12 January 2021, after he posted a video saying the speech he made to his supporters on January 6 before the Capitol riot . The company then extended the ban without an end date. It wasn’t until March 2023, after Trump announced his bid for his second presidency, that YouTube reinstated the channel . Within hours of getting his channel back, Trump posted: “I’M BACK!” accompanied by an 11-second video of him talking at a rally . Most of the payout from the Meta suit will go to Trump’s presidential library fund. The lavish ballroom is expected to cost around $200m .

title: Memes and nihilistic in-jokes: the online world of Charlie Kirk’s alleged killer
summary: 22-year-old Tyler Robinson shot and killed rightwing activist Charlie Kirk . His shooting has put the spotlight on the intersection of political violence and an increasingly nihilistic online world . In Robinson's exchanges with his roommate, who he was also romantically involved with, he appeared to have been thinking of how the ironic messages would be received . With the references, Robinson fits a modern trend of attackers leaving behind messages that not only show they are products of an online culture, but are in conversation with it . There is an enormous gulf between holding opposition to Kirk’s views and carrying out a targeted killing . And increasingly, experts say, the motivation of shooters, particularly young ones, don’t fit neatly into a traditional left-right spectrum . Instead of trying to find precise meaning in the irony soaked, trolling messages that attackers have left behind, extremism researchers argue that it’s often more useful to look at how online mediums are broadly shaping radicalization .

title: The trillion-dollar AI arms race is here
summary: Tech companies are fighting to claim the title of having the world’s most advanced AI . Google announced it was planning to spend $85bn on building out its AI and cloud infrastructure just in 2025 . Amazon has said it plans to spend $100bn in 2025 – the ‘vast majority’ of which will go to powering the AI capabilities of its cloud division . Artificial intelligence companies have come under fire for cannibalizing creative industries . Artists have seen their work used without their permission as companies train their algorithms . Adobe is trying to walk the line between developing useful AI programs and making sure artists aren’t getting the short end of the stick . The company has introduced two ‘creator-safe’ tools, that aim to tackle issues around copyright and intellectual property . In June, Mark Zuckerberg said the company planned to spend ‘hundreds of billions’ of dollars on building out a network of massive data centers across the US including one that the firm expects to be up and running in 2026.

title: Australia’s social media ban is attracting global praise – but we’re no closer to knowing how it would work
summary: Adolescence star said UK should follow Australia's lead in banning children under 16 from social media . Time magazine praised the prime minister for a 'remarkable' policy that was 'politically uncontroversial' But nine months out from the policy coming into effect, Australians are still in the dark about how our ban will work . A trial of age assurance technology is under way, with schoolchildren still being recruited to participate just weeks before the first report is due . The ban is not a major focus of the federal election campaign . But it had bipartisan support, after the Coalition pushed for it for months until the Labor government relented . There are still major concerns over how the ban will work, and who is included . When YouTube is excluded, the figure is closer to 44%. The Age Check Certification Scheme (ACCS) is due to provide a preliminary report to the government by the end of April . From there, schoolchildren will test out age estimation, assurance and verification .

title: Skype got shouted down by Teams and Zoom. But it revolutionised human connection
summary: Microsoft has decided to terminate Skype, the internet telephony company it bought in 2011 for $8.5bn (£6.6bn) Its millions of hapless users are to be herded into Microsoft Teams . This eventuality had been telegraphed for quite a while but, even so, it comes as a jolt because Skype was a remarkable venture . The internet has been around for much longer than most people realise . It goes back to the 1960s and the creation of Arpanet, a military computer network that emerged after the US had its 'Sputnik moment' The design of Arpanet's successor, the internet, started in the early 1970s and it was first switched on in January 1983 . Most people nowadays have no idea how closed and depressing telephony was in the analogue era .

title: How the roots of the ‘PayPal mafia’ extend to apartheid South Africa
summary: Musk is part of the 'PayPal mafia' of libertarian billionaires with roots in South Africa . They include Peter Thiel, the German-born billionaire venture capitalist and PayPal cofounder . David Sacks, formerly PayPal’s chief operating officer and now a leading fundraiser for Trump, was born in Cape Town . Roelof Botha, the grandson of the apartheid regime’s last foreign minister, Pik Botha, and former PayPal CFO, has kept a lower political profile but remains close to Musk . Some draw a straight line between Musk’s formative years atop a complex system of racial hierarchy as a white male, in a country increasingly at war with itself as the South African government became ever more repressive as resistance to apartheid grew, and the man we see at Trump’s side today . The week before the inauguration, Steve Bannon, Trump’s former adviser, described white South Africans as the “most racist people on earth”, questioned their involvement in US politics and said Musk was a malign influence who should go back to the country of his birth .

title: ‘The reign of terror is over’: my weird weekend partying with the triumphant tech right
summary: Silicon Valley's power players have argued that Democrats don't support the tech industry any more . Their alignment with Trump seems in part protective, an attempt to avoid being targeted by regulators or prosecutors . Many people in the tech right also resonate with the socially conservative world of the 'new right' and its openness toward, to put it mildly, reactionary politics . Most people I met over inauguration weekend were ecstatic about Trump 2.0 . And they seldom expressed concern about the friendliness between Washington and the richest people and companies on earth . The crypto community rallied behind Trump after his reversal on Bitcoin, shifting from calling it a scam to embracing light regulation . It has some overlap with the libertarian-leaning supporters of Robert F Kennedy Jr, who are similarly skeptical of centralized authority while also more likely to embrace offbeat ideas about health and wellness . As it happens, many crypto enthusiasts also supported Kennedy’s presidential campaign, and after he endorsed Trump and set himself up to be the new administration’s health secretary, Kennedy’s fans opted to join the offbeat wellbeing movement .

title: UK Meta staff ‘concerned’ over scrapping of factcheckers and DEI programmes
summary: Prospect union has written to Meta to express staff concern about the impact of the controversial decisions . It comes as Meta, which also owns WhatsApp and Instagram, is planning to cut about 5% of its global workforce . The move could affect about 3,600 employees globally amid a shake-up to Meta’s performance management system . UK employees believe that Meta’s ability to attract and retain talent in the UK, and to thrive as an inclusive business, will be severely impacted .  Prospect is seeking assurances from Meta that staff members with protected characteristics, especially those from the LGBTQ+ community, will not be disadvantaged by the company’s policy changes . Facebook owner Meta employed 6,338 people in the UK at the end of 2023, according to the most recent accounts for Facebook UK .

title: Meta’s ditching of factcheckers is potentially dangerous and a disservice
summary: Mark Zuckerberg’s announcement that Meta is to follow X in introducing user-generated notes raises serious concerns . The shift will intensify pressures on vulnerable groups, including children, minorities, gender rights advocates and LGBTQ+ communities . It risks deepening societal polarisation and further fragmenting public discourse . If Meta truly aspires to be a deliberative space driven by a ‘global collective consciousness that keeps each other accountable, the company must establish structures that penalise coercion, foster reciprocity and ensure that diverse voices are heard.  robust systems of accountability must be implemented to ensure credibility and trust.  Meta’s oversight board and previous factchecking system were steps towards enhancing the quality of deliberation. However, it appears that Trump’s agenda is now overriding the vision of individuals such as Noah Feldman, and even Helle Thorning-Schmidt, who have advocated for Meta creating a better society.

title: Historic town founded by Black Colombians fleeing slavery eyes second ‘independence’
summary: 300 years after Spain recognised San Basilio de Palenque as a slavery-free territory, residents are set to vote on becoming an independent town . The town is the most famous Colombian palenque – the name given to communities formed by formerly enslaved people who escaped bondage . Next month’s referendum is one of the final steps in that process, but there is still no indication of when the city will hold its first local elections . There is a sharp contrast between its cultural and historic significance and the profound lack of basic public services such as running water and sanitation . Young people practise traditional dances from the community . These musical styles and dances have their roots in African rhythms Cimarrn . was the term used by Spanish colonisers to refer to enslaved and formerly enslaved people . who rebelled and fled to form palenques . With its strategic location on the Caribbean, Cartagena was one of the main ports for goods and enslaved Africans under the Spanish crown in the Americas .

title: ‘Trump is killing poor people’: Caribbean village mourns victim of US strike
summary: Two men from Trinidad believed to have been killed in a US airstrike on a boat . Donald Trump has described the six killed as 'narcoterrorists' Men's relatives have accused the US of 'killing poor people' without due process . They have also accused the Trinidad and Tobago government of giving up its sovereignty to the US . Family and community members said they felt betrayed by their own government . Local fishers said they were afraid of being caught in the crossfire amid Trump's 'war on drugs' in the region . US media reported another strike on a boat in the Caribbean on Thursday . Activist David Abdulah said the Caribbean must remain a 'zone of peace' He warned there was an imminent threat to the region's sovereignty and peace .

title: Church of Norway says sorry to LGBTQ+ people for ‘shame, great harm and pain’
summary: The apology took place at the London Pub, one of Oslo's most prominent LGBTQ+ spaces . In the 1950s, the church’s bishops described gay people as a 'social danger of global proportions' In 2007, the Church of Norway began ordaining gay pastors, and same-sex couples have been able to marry in church since 2017 . The head of a network of Christian lesbians in Norway described it as 'an important reparation' and a moment that 'finally marked the end of a dark chapter in the church's history' The Church of England apologised for what it described as its 'shameful' treatment in 2023 . Globally, a handful of religious institutions have sought to make amends for their actions towards LGBTQ+ people .

title: Miss Major, trailblazing US trans rights activist and Stonewall veteran, dies aged 78
summary: Miss Major Griffin-Gracy, a trailblazer of the transgender rights movement, longtime community organizer and veteran of the Stonewall riots, died on Monday . The acclaimed activist died at her home in Little Rock, Arkansas, surrounded by family, the House of gg announced . Miss Major was one of the US’s most celebrated trans rights pioneers and elders, at the forefront of the fight for trans rights for more than five decades . She spent her final years providing a sanctuary for trans and gender-nonconforming people in her conservative home state . Her mantra, 'I'm still fucking here!', captured the joy and humor she brought to her activism and became a rallying cry for the resiliency of Black trans people . In recent years, Miss Major suffered repeated health challenges, yet she continued her work through the House Of gg, which she also nicknamed Telling It Like It Fuckin' Is (Tilifi) The organization brings trans leaders to her colorful Little Rock guest house to provide a refuge for rest and relaxation .

title: The Supremes, Marcus Garvey, Tupac Shakur: the cultural figures who inspired our Black History Month panel
summary: Two remarkable works that have profoundly influenced me are James and Wounded, both by the brilliant Percival Everett . Pan-Africanism awakened my fascination with history Zeinab Badawi Broadcaster, journalist and president of Soas University of London . For me, Winifred Atwell’s music was an early lesson in freedom YolanDa Brown Saxophonist, composer, broadcaster and chair of the British Phonographic Industry .  Gamal Abdel Nasser, of Egypt. I chose him because he is seen as an Arab leader and yet he was also very firmly anchored in the concept of pan-Africanism . Nasser arranged a marriage for Kwame Nkrumah, the first prime minister and president of Ghana, ensuring he had a wife from Egypt . Watching old footage now, I see more than show... there’s space for all of it . Atwell’s story speaks to possibility. She moved effortlessly between Chopin and boogie-woogie, and played everywhere from concert halls to variety shows .

title: Guyana in turmoil after opposition leader arrested and faces US extradition
summary: Azruddin Mohamed, 38, and his father, Nazar Mohamed, 73, were arrested in October . They face 11 charges in a Florida court, including money laundering, bribery and tax evasion . Mohamed was arrested just two months after he emerged as the surprise contender in the presidential election that kept incumbent Irfaan Ali in power . He has claimed they are victims of political persecution by Ali’s government . The case has become emblematic at a time when relations between the Caribbean nation and the US have taken on new energy significance . Last Monday, three days after Mohamed was arrested and released on bail, he was sworn in alongside the rest of the new congress. He arrived in the Lamborghini at the centre of an alleged mail fraud case against him .

title: Spirituality isn’t rigid dogma. It’s a living, breathing practice that helps make sense of an incomprehensible world
summary: I grew up between Kabul and Karachi; two cities that always felt like they were on the edge of something . In both, I learned that people survive not just through faith but through the small things they do when no one’s watching . I've come to see how these seemingly small gestures – the fragrant smoke of esfand to lift heaviness, the rhythmic pull of qawwali, the quiet assurance of a taweez tied around a wrist – hold more than superstition . They carry virtues: grounding, comfort and a deep sense of protection . As long as we live, humans will search for these quiet, innocent acts of hope and protection gestures that don’t always make sense on paper but make all the difference in the world .

title: Threats, fear and hope as Mumbai slum dwellers await the bulldozers
summary: Dharavi is one of India’s largest and most storied slums . It will be bulldozed and redeveloped by the multinational conglomerate Adani Group . The dank gullies of Dharavi sit in stark contrast to the soaring skyscrapers . Homes are built haphazardly and often without proper sanitation .  unregulated industries emit toxic smoke and the air is filled with the suffocating smell of open sewers . To some, the promise of Dharavi transformed into a glistening neighbourhood of luxury high-rises, neat parks, shiny shopping centres and homes with two toilets is an aspirational dream come true . But others, such as Mohammad Khurshid Shaikh, are resisting . They fear that this plan will turn a piece of prime Mumbai real estate into a playground for the rich, forcing out the lower-caste, migrant communities who have been there since the late 1800s . Since they began to vocally oppose the development, residents claim they have been subjected to a long-running campaign of harassment and intimidation .

title: Trump’s megalomaniac White House project fits a global trend among far-right populists
summary: Trump’s disfiguring the White House fits into a larger global trend . far-right populist leaders in many countries have used spectacular architecture to advance their political agenda . In his use of the built environment, Trump is less an example of American exceptionalism than is suggested by credulous accounts of 'Trump, ever the developer' The implicit claim is that one might avoid all kinds of propaganda online and on TV, but one cannot avoid buildings in everyday life . Even if such figures were removed from office – and of course they do everything to avoid that outcome – their edifices and monuments will remain . The pattern is usually this: one layer of history – be it the Mughal period or, in Hungary, state socialism with its modernist buildings – is removed and a reconstruction is celebrated as a return to a people’s authenticity and greatness .

title: Big? Beautiful? Donald Trump is literally ripping apart the home of US democracy. Is anyone really surprised?
summary: Demolition crews moved into the White House to knock down part of the East Wing . It was the first stage of a project Trump has advertised as the addition to the White House of a 90,000 sq ft ballroom . The ballroom will be funded via private donations, setting up yet another race to curry favour with the president . For many Americans, the demolition photos were soul-shuddering in a way that has no direct equivalence in the UK . But the building at No 10, and the living quarters in particular, have never been as iconic or emotionally charged as their US counterparts . Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here .

title: Why is Trump demolishing the White House’s East Wing? Because he wants to
summary: The 123-year-old East Wing of the White House, the home of offices for every first lady for almost half a century, is now a pile of rubble . After Trump said in July that the historic building would not be touched, it was stealthily bulldozed to make way for a $300m ballroom . Trump has said the new 90,000 sq ft ballroom is going to be paid for 100% by me and some friends of mine . A list of donors including Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft and Google have already lined up to contribute to the project . The US constitution’s 22nd amendment makes it very clear that a president cannot have more than two terms . In March, he told NBC News he was ‘not joking’ about the idea and that there were methods for doing so . And this week, Trump’s former White House chief strategist, Steven Bannon, told the Economist that the president will ‘get a third term’

title: Everybody panic – the workplace has become too ‘feminized’!
summary: Gender grifting involves explaining to less enlightened women why feminism has gone too far . You get extra points if you aren’t white, and can explain to the masses how racism is good, actually . The right has been so successful in rewriting reality, you can see gender grifting all over the homepage of the New York Times . While the Times is busy pondering whether liberal feminism has ruined the workplace, women’s rights are being rolled back around the world . In the very same week that this piece came out, Mexico’s president Claudia Sheinbaum was groped by a drunk man as she mingled with citizens on the streets of Mexico City . And in the US, the gender pay gap has widened for the second year in a row, and the Times wants us to consider whether the workplace has been too feminized . If you want a proper intellectual interrogation of gendered nonsense, I suggest you read Angela Saini’s The Patriarchs .

title: Where is the Gaza ‘peace process’ really going?
summary: In the first month, Israel has broken its own agreement at least 100 times . In 2008, Israel violated a months-long truce with Hamas by launching an operation that killed six Hamas members, then used the predictable rocket response to justify Operation Cast Lead . Nearly half of all Palestinian children killed by Israeli forces or settlers in the occupied West Bank since records began in 2005 were killed in just the past two years, 224 children since January 2023 out of 468 total . This year, Israel approved its largest settlement expansion since Oslo, 22 new illegal settlements, some deep within Palestine . The method never changes: violate the ceasefire, wait for retaliation, claim victimhood, launch the offensive you’d already planned . Just look at the West Bank, where Palestinians laid down their weapons after the sham that is the Oslo Accords. What did demilitarization bring them? More settlements, more checkpoints, more children shot by snipers, more olive groves burned, more homes demolished .

title: He told the world what was happening in El Fasher. Then they sought him out. How Sudan lost ‘a true hero of the war’
summary: Mohamed Khamis Douda has been killed in El Fasher, Sudan . His friends and family have confirmed to the Guardian that he was killed . In the months leading to El Fasher's fall, Douda said it felt as if he was being followed by drones . He spent the nights in silence and darkness, afraid of the drones and explosions he could hear around him . Each day started with the search for food . As food dwindled, he inevitably had to rely on ombaz – a residue left over from the production of crushing peanuts for oil production . People were eating cattle hides because even the ombaz had run out . When he came back online, he said people could no longer move and tried to spend their days inside their makeshift bomb shelters . The unbearable heat made it difficult to remain there . Whenever someone moves, the drones attack. I spend all my time thinking about how I can escape, he said .

title: Ministers can raise taxes if they come out fighting. But no one in this cowardly Labour government seems able
summary: In less than a month, the government will unveil a budget that will be huge in scope, and hugely painful . The public is likely to pick up a tab for £20-30bn in tax rises and spending cuts . This comes just a year after the last hugely painful budget, which was the second-largest tax raiser in postwar history . All those clenched jaws and gritted teeth surely helped at last summer’s election, when Labour secured a majority a mile wide and an inch deep . But now the British government is defined by its inability to argue . They should have spent months – years – arguing that the public realm needs investment, and laying out the stats that show the average British worker is taxed less than counterparts in most of western Europe . A few of us warned long ago that strapping oneself into a budgetary straitjacket to score a point against the party of Liz Truss was as unnecessary as any stunt by Ed Davey, and far more dangerous .

title: ‘They told me not to speak out’: the woman who took on China – and won her husband’s freedom
summary: Zeynure Hasan, 31, and Idris, 37, are Uyghurs, a mostly Muslim ethnic group . The couple had joined thousands of others who fled to Turkey in the 2010s . But if they thought they would be safe in exile, they were wrong . Idris was arrested and imprisoned on arrival in Morocco and told he was going to be deported to China . Zeynure says Turkish officials let him board the flight knowing he would be arrested when he arrived in Morocco . With her husband’s life at risk, Zeynure was not going to stay quiet . She had to do something to rescue her husband – I had to tell the truth to the world . China says it is tackling extremism through ‘controlling illegal religious activities’ and ‘vocational education and training centres’, but other countries, including the US, say its actions amount to genocide . They [the Chinese government] pushed me to speak out.

title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
summary: A powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn on Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 640 others . The US Geological Survey said the quake’s epicentre was located 22km (14 miles) south-west of the town of Khulm, and that it struck at 12.59am at a depth of 28km (17 miles) In August, an earthquake in eastern Afghanistan killed more than 2,200 people . Monday’s earthquake was also felt in Mazar-i-Sharif, the capital of the northern Balkh province, Afghan officials said . Footage on social media showed slight damage to the historic Blue Mosque, but the centuries-old site remained intact . In Badakhshan, the quake partly or completely destroyed 800 houses in one village, police said .

title: Sudan’s brutal civil war – what has happened in El Fasher?
summary: Rapid Support Forces captured El Fasher from the army after 18-month siege . RSF accused of killing hundreds of unarmed civilians in ethnically motivated attacks . Group has also been accused of hunting down specific individuals, detaining civilians, and releasing them only after receiving ransom payments . Civil war between RSF and Sudanese army began in April 2023 after a power struggle between the two forces . Both sides have been accused of a litany of human rights violations and war crimes against civilians . U.S, UN and others have determined that the RSF has committed genocide and mass rape against ethnic Masalit and non-Arab communities in Darfur . In April, the RSF killed as many as 2,000 people when it seized the Zamzam camp, which at the time housed 500,000 people .

title: Kathryn Bell obituary
summary: Kathryn Bell was a founder member of several organisations promoting creativity and human rights . In 1976, Kathryn and her partner, Elsa Wallace Beckett, set up Gemma, a support and social network in London for lesbians with disabilities . She was instrumental in setting up and administering an authors’ collective, which became Paradise Press, and has published more than 40 books to date . On her 90th birthday last year, she was presented with the Sappho in Paradise award by the International Lesbian and Gay Cultural Network, for services to LGBTQ+ literature and publishing . Kathryn is survived by two cousins, William and Anne. She is also survived by a large circle of friends and family . For confidential support call the Samaritans in the UK on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details .

title: Wednesday briefing: Making sense of the Maccabi Tel Aviv saga, where law and disorder fumbled with fandom
summary: Maccabi Tel Aviv say 'hate-filled falsehoods' have created 'toxic atmosphere' Government's efforts to make attendance possible are now academic . Family courts will no longer work on presumption that having contact with both parents is in the best interests of a child . Plans to hold summit between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin in Budapest have been put on hold as Ukraine and its European allies rallied in pushing for a ceasefire without territorial concessions from Kyiv . Almost half a million workers are to receive a pay boost after it was announced that the real living wage paid voluntarily by 16,000 UK companies will rise to £13.45 an hour in April . The decision was taken by Birmingham’s safety advisory group, which is responsible for issuing safety certificates for football matches, with the support of West Midlands police and the UK football policing unit . One plausible claim reported yesterday underlines what a toxic mess the situation has become: according to Jewish News, the final straw was Tommy Robinson’s promise to attend the match .

title: My dad cursed our family and left us. But after his death, he followed me everywhere
summary: My father stopped taking his insulin and started leaving his flat at night without his shoes . After several tests, he was diagnosed with Lewy body dementia . He moved to a nursing home in Stockholm, and I told myself everything would end well . I imagined coming by with my sons, and we would finally be able to talk about everything . But whenever I’ve gone through a breakup since, I hear my father’s voice: 'I told you not to trust anyone' He never forgave me for leaving Sweden .  Mossad had bugged his room. His plants were still full of people, and the muddy water on the floor was rising by the day. He wanted to go to Tunisia, or Paris, or New York. He had a thousand dreams, sold watches, imported perfumes, drove subways, bartended, taught languages – always dreaming of that big break that would turn everything around. But he lost a lot of people along the way. I spent my life trying to prove him wrong.

title: Wednesday briefing: The new, devastating flood risk facing nearly all of Britain
summary: Millions more homes across England, Scotland and Wales are at risk of devastating floods . In England alone, the number of properties exposed to flooding is expected to rise by more than a quarter . The picture is so bleak that, startlingly, some towns may one day have to be abandoned altogether . Insurance leaders are sounding the alarm about extreme weather events driven by the climate crisis . They warn that large swathes of housing and commercial property in densely populated areas are among the most vulnerable to devastating flooding . 'It is absolutely a sign that the climate crisis is here and escalating in the UK,' says Matthew Taylor, an environment correspondent for the Guardian . To dig into the investigation’s findings and explore what communities and the government must now do, I spoke to Matthew Taylor . WARNING: GRAPHIC CONTENT . D’Angelo, the Grammy-winning R&B singer who helped pioneer the sound of neo-soul, has died after a struggle with pancreatic cancer.

title: Trump and his media buddies are taking the muddling of reality to a whole new level
summary: Trump appeared on CBS News’s 60 Minutes on Sunday night for his first sit-down with the show in five years . He commented on how much better the network has become after its owner, Paramount, was taken over by his billionaire allies . An interview conducted by a network now owned by the president’s allies, with a head of news that he thinks is ‘great’, is part of a broader trend of US media outlets lying down and rolling over for Trump . Elon Musk has launched his own AI-powered version of Wikipedia called Grokipedia . Musk’s Grokipedia is riddled with factual errors, largely because it pulls from unreliable sources . When you make it difficult to separate opinions from facts, it becomes easier to manipulate people .

title: President JD Vance or Marco Rubio? We’re seeing the first signs of the battle over Trump’s succession
summary: Trump has threatened to defy the constitution and seek a third term . He picked out JD Vance and Marco Rubio as his most likely successors . Vance, 41, is the bro to beat, the heir apparent and dauphin to King Don . Rubio, 54, acts as prop, cheerleader and repairman . His job: to make sense of Trump’s ill-considered, hyped-up deals . As a 2016 presidential candidate, he championed traditional US alliances, human rights and foreign aid . Since he took the Trump shilling, his principled stands have mysteriously eroded . US overseas assistance budgets have been gutted, democracy promotion and human rights deprioritised, and direct US support for Ukraine eviscerated . If Vance does run, he will have to spell out what he believes . The problem is, he doesn’t know . In one policy area, this son of anti-Castro migrants is consistent: his antipathy to leftwing regimes in Cuba .

title: ‘This was a slaughter, not an operation’: the favela reeling from Rio’s deadliest police raid
summary: More than 130 people were killed during the deadliest police operation in Rio's history . Troops launched a pre-dawn assault on Alemo and Penha, two favelas . Rio officials said on Tuesday that at least 64 people had been killed . By the early hours of Wednesday the public prosecutor said the death toll had risen to 132 – higher than during So Paulo’s notorious Carandiru prison massacre in 1992 . Many of the dead men are likely to have been members of the local drug faction, the Red Command . But there was fury among the scores of people who claimed police had summarily executed the young men instead of detaining them . One had been decapitated, the person's head stashed inside an olive green pouch that was placed on the ground . No one – not the veteran crime reporters, nor the gangland preachers, nor the battle-weary favela residents – had ever seen bloodshed on this scale .
